titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Nan Britton Papers LSC.0467
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Simon Elliott and Lilace Hatayama, 2000.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2020 August 31

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-04 14:09:09 -0700.

did.unittitle: Nan Britton papers
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Nan Britton Papers (Collection 467). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Simon Elliott and Lilace Hatayama, 2000.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of correspondence, manuscripts, clippings, photographs, and memorabilia.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Warren G. Harding inscribed To Miss Nan Britton ... Sincerely, Warren G. Harding.
Photograph of Miss Abigail Victoria Harding (later Mrs. Ralph T. Lewis) inscribed: Most sincerely yours, Abigail Victoria Harding.
Photograph of Carolyn Harding (Mrs. Heber Herbert Votaw, inscribed: Yours truly, Carolyn Votaw.
Photograph of Dr. George Tryon Harding, father fo Warren G. Harding, Victoria and Carolyn Harding, inscribed: Yours truly, G.T. Harding.
Photograph of Lila Wesener, inscribed : To Miss Nan Britton -- / With and all good wishes from / her admiring friend, ' Lila Wesener.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Nan Britton's note The latter inscription was cut from the photograph because I wanted to frame the latter 'close-up' but I kept the inscription. Lila Wesener was a cousin of the Harding sisters and brothers.

did.unittitle: Wallet of Warren G. Harding,

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Nan Britton's note: ... (his name imprinted in gold), given to me by Carrie Votaw when I was a guest in their home in Tacoma Park, Washington, D.C. (see p.308, The President's Daughter).

did.unittitle: Notarized statement of Mrs. Mary Lee Britton (Nan Britton's mother) regarding a visit of Elizabeth Britton Willits (Nan Brittons sister) to Mr. Harding at Marion, Ohio, after the election,
Statement from Nan Britton's sister, Elizabeth Britton Willits, regarding her knowledge of Nan Britton's receipt of letters from Mr. Harding,
Letter from Mrs. Jack (Mary) Pusey regarding her suspicions of Mr. Harding's paternity and Nan Britton's reply (carbon copy),

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Dated per envelope. Mrs. Pusey called Mrs. P.J. Johnson in The President's Daughter. Nan Britton's note: I resided in the home (apartment) of the Puseys for two years during which time I was seeing Mr. Harding.

did.unittitle: Snapshot of Warren G. Harding which Nan Britton loved and carried for years.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Nan Britton's additional note: This one is in The President's Daughter, opposite p.60. (Snapshot sent to me by Warren G. Harding).

did.unittitle: Another Snapshot of Warren G. Harding which Nan Britton loved and carried almost as long as the one above.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Nan Britton's note: (This one acquired I don't recall how. It appears to have been taken at the White House).

Photograph of Mr. Harding taken at Edmonston Studio, Washington, D.C,

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Nan Britton's note: This was the first photograph Mr. Harding sent me - when I lived at 412 E. 58th St., New York City, with my father's college classmate's family (Mr. & Mrs. Grove D. Curtis and daughter Anna), in the spring of 1917.

did.unittitle: Newspaper picture of Abigail and Carolyn,

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Nan Britton's note: ... displayed in the Pach Fifth Avenue window in August of 1923. Returning from France on learning of Mr. Harding's death, I chanced to see it and bought this copy.
